awd_titl_txt: Parametrization, Embedding and Extension Problems in Metric Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Geometric function theory is a field of mathematics that was developed starting in the 1920s in order to study analytic functions from a geometric point of view, and was later developed to what is known today as analysis of metric spaces. The advantage of a geometric approach, is that first order differential calculus and geometric measure theory can be extended from the classical Euclidean or Riemannian settings to the realm of spaces without a priori smooth structure (such as fractal spaces). Results and techniques in geometric function theory have recently found important applications in geometric group theory, structure of manifolds and analysis on fractals. Furthermore, besides their mathematical importance, physical applications of these theories include reconstruction theory, study of thin films, control theory, graphic imaging and analysis of large data sets.

This project features new approaches to three long-standing problems in the realm of geometric function theory that bring together several fields in analysis and geometry including geometric topology, sub-Riemannian geometry, PL geometry and geometric measure theory. The first problem aims at recognizing the intrinsic qualities of a metric space, from which a "nice" parametrization (e.g. quasisymmetric, Holder, bi-Lipschitz) by the Euclidean unit sphere or the Euclidean space can be recovered. The principal investigator proposes to relate forms of discrete curvature with global parametrizations in high dimensions. The second problem asks for conditions for which an embedding of a set into a Euclidean space with some desired properties (e.g. quasisymmetric, bi-Lipschitz) can be extended to the whole Euclidean space with the same properties. Finally, the third problem concerns the bi-Lipschitz embedability of big sets of a sub-Riemannian manifolds (such as the Heisenberg group) into some Euclidean space. Results in this direction will shed new light on the structure of the space and will improve our understanding of its geometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Geometric function theory is a field of mathematics that was developed starting in the 1920s in order to study analytic functions from a geometric point of view, and was later developed to what is known today as analysis of metric spaces. The advantage of a geometric approach, is that first order differential calculus and geometric measure theory can be extended from the classical Euclidean or Riemannian settings to the realm of spaces without a priori smooth structure (such as fractal spaces). Results and techniques in geometric function theory have recently found important applications in geometric group theory, structure of manifolds and analysis on fractals. Furthermore, besides their mathematical importance, physical applications of these theories include reconstruction theory, study of thin films, control theory, graphic imaging and analysis of large data sets.


This project featured new approaches to several long-standing problems in the realm of geometric function theory that bring together several fields in analysis and geometry including complex dynamics, sub-Riemannian geometry, and geometric measure theory. The first problem aims at recognizing the intrinsic qualities of a metric space, from which a "nice" parametrization (Lipschitz, Holder) by the unit interval can be recovered. The second problem is concerned with classifying the metric spaces which can be embedded in a Euclidean space in a way that their geometry is not distorted too much. Results in this direction shed new light on the structure of the space and improve our understanding of its geometry. Finally the third cluster of questions is on analytic properties of Cantor sets with small dimension.


On the first group of problems, in a series of 3 papers the PI studied a form of "fractional rectifiability" of sets, i.e. infinite sets which are contained in the images of Holder continuous curves. Notable advances include a rejuvenation of Martin and Mattila's theory of fractional rectifiabiilty of sets and measures in work by the PI and Badger; a new parameterization technique developed by the PI, M. Badger and L. Naples which led to the Holder Traveling Salesman Theorem; a study of of self-similar sets and their Holder parameterizations.


On the second group of problems, the PI jointly with V. Chousionis, S. Li, and S. Zimmerman, examined the bi-Lipschitz embedabbility of several canonical subsets of the Heisenberg group, one of the most famous metric spaces in sub-Riemannian geometry. Furthermore, in a joint work with G. C. David, the PI investigated the bi-Lipschitz geometry of quasiconformal trees (metric trees with controlled geometry) and proved that under certain conditions, such trees admit a desirable bi-Lipschitz embedding. The complete solution of the bi-Lipschitz embedabbility of quasiconformal trees was obtained later by the PI jointly with G. C. David and S. Eriksson-Bique. The latter result presents the most (topologically) complicated class of metric spaces which all admit a bi-Lipschitz embedding.


On the third group of problems, in a series of 4 papers, the PI studied analytic properties of "thin" Cantor sets in three different directions. Firstly, the PI provided a quasiconformal uniformization of Cantor sets with controlled geometry. Secondly, in two papers joint with A. Fletcher and D. Stoertz, the PI investigated Cantor sets that arise as Julia sets of UQR maps (the natural analogue of holomorphic maps in higher dimensions). Finally, jointly with A. Fletcher, the PI showed that certain bi-Lipschitz homeomorphisms of the plane that spiral around a Cantor set with small dimension, can be decomposed to almost isometries. The latter result gave a solution for a special case of the Decomposition Problem.


The research activities carried out during the four years of this award resulted in 6 publications, 2 manuscripts awaiting publication, and 2 additional manuscripts under review. High-quality mathematics journals where this work appeared included the Journal of Geometric Analysis, the Advances of Mathematics, and the Proceedings of the AMS. The research results obtained were broadly disseminated in numerous conferences and research seminars at university across the United States, including Princeton (12/21) and Texas A&M (8/22). Broader impact of this work includes participation of an undergraduate (later graduate) student in the research projects.


Last Modified: 11/09/2022
Modified by: Vyron S Vellis
